metadata.title: Diabetic Foot Ulcer
anatomical location body part affected: Foot/skin and subcutaneous tissue, including muscle
description: Diabetic foot ulcer (DFU) is a long-term  complication that develops in approximately 15% to 25% of patients withtype 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) (1,2,3,41)
DFUs occur most often on the plantar surface of the forefoot(hallux, first metatarsal head) and heel, but alsoin the nail folds and nail beds (1,2,3)
Uninfected DFUs are characterized by ischemia, swelling, callus, deformity, and loss of sensation due to neuropathy (1,3)

Uninfected DFUs represent the pivotal first and second stages (Wagner grades 1 and 2) in the natural history of diabetic foot disease(1,2,3) –Wagner Grading System -0: Intact skin -1: Superficial ulcer of skin or subcutaneous tissue -2: Ulceration extends through dermis; may extend into tendon and bone capsule -3: Deep ulcer with osteomyelitis or abscess -4: Gangrene of affected toes or distal half of foot -5: Proximal foot gangrene
Prompt treatment and surveillance of DFU is imperative because in the United States it is estimated that only 50% of ulcers close within one year (2)
Pressure-relieving  interventions, meticulous wound care, and management education may prevent progression of the DFU to the stages of infection (Wagner grades 3–5)(1,2,3,4,5,6,7)

This Clinical Review focuses on the identification and treatment of Wagner grade 1 or 2 DFUs. Patients with chronic infected DFUs (for example, abscess, osteomyelitis, or gangrene) often require surgical management to accomplish limb salvage and prevent amputation

ICD-10 codes.E10.5: insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus with peripheral circulatory complications
ICD-10 codes.E11.5: non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus with peripheral circulatory complications
ICD-10 codes.E11.621: Type 2 diabetes mellitus with foot ulcer
ICD-10 codes.E14.5: unspecified diabetes mellitus with peripheral circulatory complications
ICD-10 codes.L97: ulcer of lower limb, not elsewhere classified (ICD codes provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage
Medicare Part B covers the purchase of custom shoes when the certifying physician identifies a risk factor for ulcer formation and submits appropriate documentation
presentation signs and symptoms: Foot wounds and impaired skin integrity(e.g., dystrophic toenails, callus, ulceration, crack, puncture, abrasion, blister, dryness); often bilateral(1,2)
Burning sensation in early stage followed by tingling and then numbness(2)
Structural changes (e.g., toe deformity, prominent metatarsal head) (2,3,7)
Weak intrinsic foot muscle function related to neuropathy (2,4,7)
Conservative gait strategy (i.e., slower walking speed, wide base, prolonged double support time)(5) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Does the physician’s prescription include a functional mobility examination or is the referral limited to foot care only?
Lack of specific consent from patient and referring physician to perform the examination

Inform physician immediately on finding evidence consistent with any of the following: –Charcot foot (flatfoot deformity without pain or sensation), because of the associated risk for chronic deformity (see Clinical Review… Charcot-Marie-Tooth  Disease in Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708624 for more information) –Necrotizing fasciitis, a condition requiring emergency surgery -Symptoms may include pain in area of lesion that is worse than would be expected by the appearance of the lesion, flu-like  symptoms, drop in blood pressure –Unresolved gangrene infection –Osteomyelitis (see Clinical Review…Osteomyelitis ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708482 for more information)
Do not perform the exam if patient is unable to follow directions due to cognitive impairment unless legal caretaker understands and provides consent

causes: Repetitive biomechanical stress and high pressure/shear forces on bony areas of foot(1,2,3)
Foreign bodies in footwear and poor fitting footwear, usually secondary to reduced protective sensation from diabeticperipheral neuropathy(6)
Poor adherence to medical instructions for foot care and prevention(3)
Pathological changes in blood vessels, nerves, and osteo-articular  structures related to DM that impair skin integrity andcause ischemic wounds(1,2,5)
pathogenesis: The formation of a callus usually proceeds the development of a DFU (6)

Hyperglycemia in DM causes nonenzymatic glycosylation of soft tissues associated with numerous pathological changesseen in DFUs (e.g., decreased skin thickness, increased skin hardness, thickened tendons, decreased bone density, atrophyof fat pad and muscle)(5)
Peripheral arterial occlusive disease in the femoral, popliteal, and tibial vessels decreases capillary blood flow andoxygenation to the diabetic foot at risk(1,2)
Peripheral neuropathy can reduce protective sensation in the affected foot.(1,2,4) Patients typically adopt a conservative gaitstrategy (5)
Impaired wound healing in DFUs is related to arterial insufficiency and glycosylation(1,2)

Non-limb-threatening  infections are usually monomicrobial (e.g., Streptococcus , Staphylococcus ).Limb-threatening infections are often multimicrobial (gram-positive  cocci, gram-negative  bacilli, anaerobic bacilli)(6)

Early intervention for patients with Wagner grade 1 or 2 DFU is necessary to reduce invasive infection. Inpatient care isrecommended after invasive foot infection develops and includes systemic antibiotic therapy, vascular laboratory testing ofartery limb perfusion, and surgical debridement of infected tissue (54)
Wagner grades 3 and 4 DFUs are severely infected (e.g., osteomyelitis, gangrene) and require limb salvage, oftenfootamputation (6,54)

Chronic heel ulcers pose the highest risk for DFU amputations.(7)Authors ofa 19-year  follow-up  study (N = 1,381) inDenmark found that men less than 65 years of age with DM and patients with DM-related  comorbidities had the highestrisk for DFU amputations (30)
risk factors ,,,,: Hyperglycemia; i.e., elevated fasting blood glucose and glycosylated hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels

Peripheral artery disease (PAD)–PAD and peripheral neuropathy oftenco-occur  with DFU. Presence of PAD with or without peripheral neuropathy canbe found in 50% of diabetic patients with lower limb lesions. The presence of peripheral neuropathy may mask typicalclinical symptoms of PAD such as claudication and pain at rest, so that a foot ulcer is the first sign of previously unknownPAD(38)
Foot deformity that predisposes to skin breakdown and callus formation
Risk factors for peripheral arterial disease; i.e., hypertension, dyslipidemia, smoking, obesity
Improperly fitting footwear that causes excessive pressure/shear on bony areas
In-shoe  peak plantar pressure of 200 kilopascals (kPa) or more is associated with increased risk of DFU, based on a 2013review of 70 studies(31)General Contraindications/Precautions

contraindications precautions to examina: Does the physician’s prescription include a functional mobility examination or is the referral limited to foot care only?
Lack of specific consent from patient and referring physician to perform the examination

Inform physician immediately on finding evidence consistent with any of the following: –Charcot foot (flatfoot deformity without pain or sensation), because of the associated risk for chronic deformity (see Clinical Review… Charcot-Marie-Tooth  Disease in Adults ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708624 for more information) –Necrotizing fasciitis, a condition requiring emergency surgery -Symptoms may include pain in area of lesion that is worse than would be expected by the appearance of the lesion, flu-like  symptoms, drop in blood pressure –Unresolved gangrene infection –Osteomyelitis (see Clinical Review…Osteomyelitis ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708482 for more information)
Do not perform the exam if patient is unable to follow directions due to cognitive impairment unless legal caretaker understands and provides consent

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: The development of DFUs is strongly associated with biomechanical stress and pressure on bony areas of the foot, especially in the presence of peripheral neuropathy and uncontrolled hyperglycemia.(31) When was the ulcer first noticed? How has it progressed since onset? Note the probable mechanism of the wounding (i.e., whether from extrinsic biomechanical stress or internal pathophysiological changes)

course of treatment.medical management: Has the patient received counseling on preventing diabetic complications, including advice on diet, exercise, and weight control?(8) Is patient compliant with these preventive measures as well as with regular selfskin  inspection? Has the patient been under the care of a podiatrist? Is medical treatment controlling blood glucose? Are there any complications related to peripheral arterial disease? Was an orthopedic shoe or total contact cast prescribed for offloading? Does the patient use an ambulatory assistive device or wheelchair because of reduced functional mobility? Has a specific dressing been prescribed for the patient’s ulcer? Advanced wound therapies such as bioengineered skin substitutes, topical growth factors, and stromal matrices may be used when wounds are chronic(39) Typical indication for advanced therapies is presence of wounds that have not achieved a 50% reduction in wound size after 4 weeks of standard wound care(39)
surgical management: Surgical management:  Was any surgical intervention performed? If so, what was the date of surgery and the outcome? Was the foot immobilized in a cast or a removable orthosis? Were there any complications?
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness Drugs commonly prescribed for patients with DFU include insulin and oral glucose-lowering  agents. Metformin is the most popular firstchoice treatment for type 2 diabetes.(8) Has patient been compliant with taking medications? Systemic antibiotics are usually prescribed for serious infection Authors of a 2017 Cochrane review found low-certainty  evidence that use of an antimicrobial dressing instead of a nonantimicrobial dressing may promote healing of DFUs over a medium-term  follow-up period (55) Is a topical medication being used on the ulcer? Is the patient being treated for cardiovascular disease?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Ask about findings of laboratory tests related to diabetes (e.g., fasting blood glucose and HbA1c levels). Was a bone scan done to rule out infection or osteomyelitis?
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Has patient tried a restricted diet for diabetes, or exercise and weight loss program for diabetes control? Are herbal remedies or topical agents being used?
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical therapy for lower extremity musculoskeletal conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document whether the patient has any DFU symptoms. What does the patient associate with increased or decreased DFU symptoms? Does the patient have a history of claudication?
history of present illness.body chart: Use chart of foot to document location and symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -Foot ulcers, wounds, and dystrophic changes in skin -Inflammation/infection/swelling -Impaired foot mobility -Functional changes such as poor posture, balance, or walking ability -Altered or antalgic gait -Disability in ADLs
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment. Specifically address if pain is the primary symptom and whether it is present now and how much
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document whether there are changes in symptoms throughout the day and night (i.e., a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night directly related to foot symptoms
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms that patient may be experiencing, such as lower extremity muscle weakness, poor balance, or arthritic pain. Is the patient at increased risk of falls?
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any respiratory compromise Barriers to learning -Is patient communication/education limited by language, hearing, vision, or cognitive impairment?

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of lower extremity problems, previous ulcer, or amputation?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Are there other medical problems, such as heart disease, pulmonary disease, cancer, dementia, psychiatric disorders, movement dysfunction, kidney problems, or impaired vision?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient whether any musculoskeletal problems or functional concerns exist in addition to the diabetic foot condition

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Question about use of tobacco, alcohol, and/or recreational drugs. Does the work environment or recreational activities require special footwear? How can the patient compensate to participate in desired occupational, recreational, or social activities during the period of treatment?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Determine the extent to which symptoms interfere with ADLs or require use of adaptive equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Are there barriers in the home that impede access, such as stairs? What modifications are needed? -Does the patient live with family members or caregivers?  -Patients with visual difficulties, physical constraints impairing movement, or cognitive problems that affect their ability to assess the condition of the foot will need other persons such as family members to assist(40)

relevant tests and measures.general: Include functional tests and measures, especially if the physician has specified a full patient ›Relevant tests and measures:  Include functional tests and measures, especially if the physician has specified a full patient assessment. A comprehensive approach will include visual inspection, foot pulse palpation, skin temperature measurement, and shoe assessment, as well as gait, orthopedic, neurologic, and vascular exams (56) •Anthropometric measurements:  Document height, weight, and BMI. Is there a leg-length  difference?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the fit and patient’s use of prescribed ambulatory assistive device or wheelchair. Otherwise, evaluate for suitable ambulatory assistive device. Determine the need for supportive/protective equipment/ orthotics and devices for ADLs (e.g., is a “sock aid” and/or shoehorn indicated or being used properly and consistently?)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess standing static and dynamic balance on both feet (eyes open vs. closed), as well as in single-leg  stance, if applicable. Consider using Berg Balance Scale assessment or Functional Reach Test as indicated
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess dorsalis pedis and posterior tibialis pulses bilaterally
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess ability in transfers (e.g., chair to stand), stair climbing, and walking ability. Utilize FIM or Timed Up & Go (TUG) test, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe for altered/antalgic gait pattern. Assess lower extremity/rearfoot alignment, movement of foot in barefooted walking, and width of stance. Measure normal walking speed (e.g., for 20 meters). Use Dynamic Gait Index (DGI), as indicated. DFU is associated with slower walking speed, wide base, and prolonged double support time(5)Assess forefoot flexibility (pronate and supinate forefoot while holding the heel in neutral position). Assess passive accessory motion at the talocrural, subtalar, cuboid, tarsometatarsal, metatarsophalangeal, and interphalangeal joints. Assess integrity of the ankle ligaments
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength in ankle plantarflexion, dorsiflexion, inversion, eversion, and forefoot adduction/ abduction. Assess ability to perform heel raise in single-leg  stand. Assess lower extremity functional strength –Neuropathic DFU is associated with decreased intrinsic foot muscle strength.(4) Test intrinsic muscle strength, toe extension, abduction of big toe
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess foot type: rectus, pes planus, or pes cavus
Assess for change in foot color on dependency and for texture/turgor
Examine for cuts/cracks, abrasions, blisters, and minor infections (e.g., tinea pedis)
Inspect callus for color and thickness (debride, if necessary, pending approval from physician)
Inspect for dystrophic nails (thick, discolored) or ingrown nails
Examine metatarsal heads (especially great toe) and heel for plantar pressure ulcers, and dorsum of toes for lesions
Measure length and width of foot ulcer
Inspect foot ulcer for involvement of underlying tissues (debride, if necessary, pending approval from physician)
Palpate for nodules along Achilles tendon
Inspect for phalangeal structural abnormalities such as hammer toe, claw toe, or hallux valgus
Inspect for type of shoe, excessive/uneven wear, distortion, and inadequate support

Does patient wear socks? If so, inspect socks for foreign bodies, staining, and excessive wear •Pain/tenderness:  Assess with V AS or numeric scale. Foot pain is usually minimal or absent in patients with deep ulceration
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and passive ROM of foot in plantar flexion, dorsiflexion, inversion, eversion, supination, and pronation. Assess ROM of hallux. Assess flexibility of Achilles tendon (expect tight calf muscle group)
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: Home-care  assessment may be indicated for patients with restricted mobility. Ask patient to demonstrate how he/she inspects feet and note any difficulty getting lower extremity into appropriate position. Note patient’s ability to dress self, and especially ability to don and doff socks and shoesAssess for sensory changes in affected foot (e.g., tactile sensation [cotton], proprioception, temperature, deep pressure, and vibration with tuning fork) in the distribution of the superficial  peroneal nerve (dorsum of foot) and deep peroneal nerve (first web space), as well as intrinsic muscle weakness in tibial nerve distribution (interossei and lumbricals)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess Achilles and patellar deep tendon reflexesAssess for foot edema with ankle girth and figure-8 measurements of circumference
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special testsA 10-gram  nylon monofilament is pressed against the foot with just enough pressure to bend the filament. Failure of the patient to feel the filament is positive for sensory neuropathy and increases risk for DFU. Replace filament on a regular basis, as repeated use (≤ 30 applications) was found to decrease the force needed to bend it(9) –Foot Function Index (FFI), a 23-item,  foot-specific  questionnaire with three subscales that assess foot function in terms of pain, disability, and activity(10) –Inlow’s 60-second  Diabetic Foot Screen Tool was found to have excellent interrater and intra-rater  reliability(11) –Quality of life Assessments (e.g., SF-36)

contraindications precautions: Skin conditions such as atopic eczema, ichthyosis, and senile pruritus
Skin ulcers, caused by venous insufficiency, edema, or lymphedema
Post-op  surgical incisions with dehiscence, sutures, or staples
Tissue flaps and recent skin grafts
electrotherapy contraindications precaut: Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor is present in the area
In the area of DVT or thrombophlebitis
Over epiphyseal plates of growing bones
Use caution in patients with sensory deficits and in patients who are unable to communicate sensory deficits
Use caution if patient has circulatory impairments
Use caution over plastic or metal implants
Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
Do not use laser with pregnant women, patients with epilepsy, or patients with infections
Do not use over the unclosed fontanelles of children
Do not use over cancerous lesions, the mediastinum, areas of impaired sensation, sympathetic ganglia, the vagus nerve, the gonads, the cornea, endocrine glands, or hemorrhaging lesions
Goggles with an appropriate optical density rating should be worn by the patient
other: Use a sterile field and sterile techniques when treating foot lesions
Dressings that retain moisture are contraindicated in the presence of infection
Allow wound healing prior to weight-bearing  on the affected area (e.g., the heel). Orthopedic devices can facilitate early functional mobility (see Treatment summary  below)

Patients with peripheral neuropathy are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis regarding use of modalities are mentioned below. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in decision making

Electrotherapy:  contraindications/precautions (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below provided potential benefits outweigh the possible risks)(12)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: DFU/unhealed wound(s); risk of amputation; impaired standing balance, general mobility, and walking ability; increased risk of falls; poor wound management, possibly secondary to lack of knowledge of foot care and risks for DFU treatment _ See research cited aboveAllow up to 20 weeks for wound healingAt least daily cleansing and dressing. Patient compliance with foot hygiene and skin care Impaired intrinsic foot muscle strength and flexibilityImprove foot strength and ROMTherapeutic exercise _ Ankle and foot resistance exercises with elastic band _ _ _Gradually progress repetitions and frequency of exercises. Daily repetition of exercisesProvide the patient with home program for strengthening, stretching, and aerobic conditioning Reduced balance and walking ability; dysfunctional gait pattern; increased risk of falls _ _ _ Impaired intrinsic foot joint mobilityImproved functional mobility, gait stability, and gait pattern; reduced falls riskFunctional training and gait reeducation _ Gait reeducation should aim to reduce the prolonged stance time and the increased rearfoot and forefoot pressures that have been found in patients with diabetic neuropathy(5)Slowly progress weight-bearing activity. Wean from assistive devices when appropriatePatient education. Provide patient and family/ caregivers with written instructions regarding exercises and functional activities that can be performed at home and correct use and/or application of equipment, activity modification  Foot ulceration related to increased plantar pressures _ _Ulcer prevention and wound healing _ _Protective footwear and ambulatory aids _ Custom shoes, total contact cast, or posterior walking splint. Use of ambulatory device to decrease weight bearing on the affected foot _ _
prognosis: Lifetime risk for a foot ulcer in patients with DM is 15 to 25% (1,2,3,41)
Studies indicate that approximately 90% of Wagner grade 1 and 2 DFUs heal with comprehensive treatment that includes control of infection and offloading of the wound (1,2,3,6,7,54,56)
Healing of small superficial DFUs typically takes 4 to 10 weeks with optimal management, although deep ulcers may take as long as 20 weeks to heal(13,14)

A simple model to predict which neuropathic DFUs will not heal with standard care has been developed –The model assigns points if the wound is older than 2 months, larger than 2 cm2, or has a grade ≥ 3 (on a 6-point  scale)(15) –The model counted 1 point for each. The probability that a wound would not heal is 35% for a score of 0, 47% for a score of 1, 66% for a score of 2, and 81% for a score of 3

After an initial DFU, risk of re-ulceration  is high Inadequate offloading footwearis a primary factor (42,43) –General risk factors for re-ulceration  can be categorized as disease-related, biomechanical, or behavioral(43)
Poor control of DM is a major risk factor for DFU recurrence, based on a prospective 3-year  follow-up  study (N = 73) in the Czech Republic(32)

Pre-hospital  delay among patients with diabetic foot problems contributes to poor outcomes, based on a retrospective study of data from 270 patients in China(44) –Nine variables were associated with a longer pre-hospital  delay: no previous ulcer, no health insurance, poor housing conditions, low income level, low educational level, infrequent foot inspection, few follow-up  medical visits, absence of diabetic foot education, and lack of knowledge of foot lesion warning signals –Longer delays increased the risk of amputation and mortality
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Orthopedic, vascular, or plastic surgeon for consultation and sharp debridement of DFU, as needed. Orthotist/pedorthist for shoe modifications, orthoses, and orthopedic footwear to correct causative pressures. Podiatrist/orthopedist for surgical consult to correct deformities. Nutritionist for dietary intervention. Nursing for acute wound care
other considerations: Use of hyperbaric oxygen in the treatment of DFU may be associated with ulcer healing in select patients.(45)However, authors of a multicenter randomized trial (N = 120) in the Netherlands found that addition of hyperbaric oxygen to standard care for DFU did not significantly improve complete wound healing or limb salvage after 12 months of treatment (57)

Results of clinical trials show that human skin equivalents, such as human fibroblast-derived  dermal substitute, and allografts consisting of human amnion/chorion membrane promote wound closure and result in more frequent and rapid healing of DFUs when compared to standard care(39)

Electronic protective footwear for patients with DFU is currently under development –A wireless orthotic shoe composed of lightweight embedded systems and non-invasive  sensors for diabetic patients with peripheral neuropathy may someday be commercially available(28) –A “smart” insole prototype with pressure and tissue healing electronic monitoring has been developed in Brazil(29)
treatment summary: The following suggestions to enhance the healing of chronic ulcers of the foot in diabetes are provided by the 2016 guidelines from the International Working Group on the Diabetic Foot:(53) –Clean ulcers regularly with clean water or saline, debride them when possible in order to remove debris from the wound surface, and dress them with a sterile, inert dressing to control excessive exudate and maintain a warm, moist environment in order to promote healing. (GRADE strength of recommendation: strong; quality of evidence: low) –In general, remove slough, necrotic tissue, and surrounding callus with sharp debridement in preference to other methods, taking relative contraindications such as severe ischemia into account. (strong; low) –Select dressings principally on the basis of exudate control, comfort, and cost. (strong; low) –Do not use antimicrobial dressings with the goal of improving wound healing or preventing secondary infection. (strong; moderate) –Consider the use of systemic hyperbaric oxygen therapy, even though further blinded and randomized trials are required to confirm its cost-effectiveness,  as well as to identify the population most likely to benefit from its use. (weak; moderate) –Topical negative pressure wound therapy may be considered in postoperative wounds even though the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness  of the approach remain to be established. (weak; moderate) –Do not select agents reported to improve wound healing by altering the biology of the wound, including growth factors, bioengineered skin products and gases, in preference to accepted standards of good quality care. (strong; low) –Do not select agents reported to have an impact on wound healing through alteration of the physical environment, including through the use of electricity, magnetism, ultrasound, and shockwaves, in preference to accepted standards of good quality care. (strong; low) –Do not select systemic treatments reported to improve wound healing, including drugs and herbal therapies, in preference to accepted standards of good quality care. (strong; low)

Standard foot care : In the office setting, this includes gentle irrigation twice daily with normal saline or a surfactant cleanser to remove contamination and for mechanical debridement, followed by dressing(16) –Dead tissue and debris should be debrided from the ulcer to obtain a pink and granulating wound base –Superficial debridement can be accomplished by water spray using a sterile 18-gneedle and 30-ml  syringe or a commercial sprayer.(17) However, hyperkeratotic and necrotic tissue usually require surgical trimming  –Evidence is lacking to support the use of alginate dressings, hydrocolloid dressings, or foam dressings for increasing the healing rate of DFUs compared with basic wound contact dressings -Based on 3 separate Cochrane reviews that compared alginate dressings with standard contact dressings (6 trials, 375 participants),(18) hydrocolloid dressings with standard contact dressings (4 trials, 511 participants),(19) and foam dressings with standard contact dressings (6 trials, 157 participants)(34) –Traditional low-adherent  dressings that retain moisture can be used if the DFU is not infected, but are contraindicated in the presence of infection(20) –Change dressings at least daily –Treat infected wounds with the prescribed antibiotic –Patient education should include infection control and offloading of the area around DFU –Remind patients to avoid warm foot baths and heating pads (because of risk for skin burning) and to avoid using harsh topical agents such as hydrogen peroxide, iodine (e.g., Betadine), and astringents (e.g., witch hazel)

Orthopedic devices : Offloading-pressure  devices may prevent DFU, improve healing, and reduce recurrence(2,21,22,34) –Assistive devices to relieve WB (e.g., crutches, walkers, custom relief orthotic walkers [CROWs], or wheelchair) –Special shoes/inserts – custom shoes, depth shoes, diabetic boots, forefoot and heel relief shoes, and custom inserts –Total contact cast (TCC) –Authors of a 2013 Cochrane systematic review of 7 trials (366 participants) found that non-removable,  pressure-relieving casts were more effective for healing plantar DFUs than removable casts or dressings alone(22) –In a 2-year  follow-up  study in Spain, customized orthotics (N = 200 feet) that significantly reduced mean peak plantar pressure (to well below 200 kPa) decreased the re-ulceration  rate from 79% to 15% (44) –Authors of a 2016 systematic review found good-quality  evidence supporting the use of non-removable  offloading support interventions in order to provide pressure relief to prevent forefoot ulcer recurrences(50) –In patients treated with a TCC there was a higher proportion of healed wounds and faster healing time compared to those who were treated with healing sandals or a shear-reducing  foot bed(51) -Based on a 12-week  single-blind  RCT in the United States -Seventy-three  patients with DFU were randomized into three groups: TCC, healing sandals, or removable boot with shear-reducing  foot bed -Results show that patients treated with the TCC had a higher proportion of wounds healed (69.6%) compared to patients treated with healing sandals (44.5%) or removable boot with shear-reducing  foot bed (22.2%)

Modalities : Several treatment modalities have been reported in small studies to improve DFU healing. Authors of a 2013 systematic review of 8 RCTs (N = 325 participants) found that evidence is lacking to support the general use of electrophysical modalities for managing DFUs(35) –Low level laser therapy (LLLT): results of an RCT (N = 68) in India showed that LLLT increased the percentage of ulcer area reduction over 15 days compared to controls who received conventional treatment for DFU(27) -On the basis of the ulcer size, the duration of exposure to LLLT was calculated to deliver 2–4 J/cm2  at 60 mW, 5 kHz, daily for 15 days –Foot humidifier: A device that delivered warm, humidified air with a noncontact dressing (3 hours daily, 5 days per week, 8 weeks) improved ulcer healing time versus standard care in a case series in the United States(23) –Electrical stimulation (ES):Several different applications of ES have been described to promote wound healing, including direct current, alternating current, high-voltage  pulsed current, low-intensity  direct current, and pulsatile electrostatic current. Evidence is lacking to support any one approach because of the variability in the parameters of ES application usedin reported studies -Low-intensity  direct current -Authors of a study conducted in Iran found that low intensity cathodal direct current electrical stimulation at sensory threshold effectively increased the plasma level of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and nitric oxide (NO) in patients with diabetic foot ulcers. VEGF and NO were associated with improved blood flow and tissue temperature, thereby promoting healing(46)  -Pulsatile electrostatic field (PESF)(52) -Authors of a study conducted in Italy suggested that use of PESF can accelerate ulcer wound healing in patients with type 2 diabetes. PESF is noninvasive and works by reducing the formation of rouleaux, increasing metabolic activity, and increasing vasomotor function –Ultrasound therapy: -Authors of a pilot study in the United States found that more frequent use of non-contact  low-frequency  ultrasound (NCLF-US)  was effective for treating DFUs by inhibiting pro-inflammatory  cytokines(47) -Profiles of cytokines/proteinase/growth factors in wound fluid and biopsied tissue were quantified in 12 subjects with chronic DFUs -Subjects were randomized to receive standard care, NCLF-US  once per week, or NCLF-US  3 times per week. Thrice weekly application resulted in the best wound area reduction –Air massage: Authors of a study in South Africa found that the experimental group that received compressed air massage to tissue around the ulcer (15 to 20 minutes, 5 days per week) reduced the time to healing by 25 days (30.1%) compared to standard-care-only  group(24) –Authors of a 2010 systematic review concluded that negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT), a vacuum technique to facilitate drainage, is safe and can accelerate DFU healing.(25)However, authors of a 2013 Cochrane review of 5 RCTs (N = 605 participants) found that the current evidence was insufficient or uncertain to support the use of NPWT for treating DFUs(36)

Therapeutic exercise : –Individualized moderate exercise training (ET) is safe and effective for blood glucose control in most patients with type 2 DM.(33) However, patients with DFUs should receive physician clearance before starting a new exercise program -Physician clearance for ET is mandatory if exercise-related  adverse signs/symptoms are documented in the patient’s medical history -Exercise without physician supervision is contraindicated if patient has known heart disease -Adapt therapeutic exercises for ambulatory patients with functional limitations (e.g., poor balance, restricted WB status, poor coordination) to reduce risk of falls –Recommendations for footcare in the American Diabetes Association’s Standards of Medical Care include consideration of exercise for patients with significant claudication or a positive ankle-brachial  index (indicative of LE arterial disease)(40) –Authors of an RCT (N = 29 participants with DM and peripheral neuropathy whose walking ability was not limited by diabetic foot disease) in the United States found that standing and walking (WB) exercises (progressive balance, flexibility, strengthening, and aerobic training) 3 times per week for 12 weeks increased 6MWT scores and daily step count significantly more than the same exercises done in sitting or lying (non-WB)(37) . Patient education on compliance regarding foot hygiene, skin care, and proper footwear Results of a study conducted in the Netherlands indicate that low compliance with appropriate footwear is not explained by the usability of the footwear (factors such as weight, difficulty with donning and doffing, and appearance)(48) –153 patients with diabetes, peripheral neuropathy, prior plantar foot ulceration, and newly prescribed custom-made footwear were recruited to participate –Although the usability of the footwear was perceived acceptable to good, the footwear use was low. However, only 42% of patients used their prescribed footwear more than 60% of daytime hours –The only factor found to determine footwear use was how patients perceived the benefit of using them. Only 5% mentioned foot protection as a priority –These results suggest a need for more effective education of patients on the therapeutic value of the preventive interventions to protect against potential complications
Appropriate off-loading  and continuing diabetes education are preventive treatment for DFUs(56)
A comprehensive program focused on foot-specific  patient education, skin and nail care, and protective footwear can lower the incidence of DFUs and amputation(8)
Patients with loss of peripheral sensation should be educated on ways to substitute other sensory modalities (e.g., hand palpation, visual inspection) for surveillance of early foot problems(40)

The Ipswich Touch Test can be used by a nonprofessional (friend, relative, caregiver) in the home to detect loss of foot sensation(49) Based on a study (N = 331 patients with diabetes) in the United Kingdom The test comprises light touching of the tips of the patient’s first, third, and fifth toes of each foot with the tip of the tester’s index finger for 1 to 2 seconds with the patient’s eyes closed The diagnostic standard, done by a trained health professional, was pressure perception using standard 10-g monofilament
